The format of the file follows the Apache Tomcat digest file conventions.
A staging unit test in the CloudController consults this digest and verifies
that the contents of the Tomcat package used by the CloudController matches it.
Updated manifest to point the destination of the Tomcat package to the new
staging gem.

Change-Id: I55240da1de25b0dd596c8040b753c2c1dc6c2929

Cloud ApplicationContextInitializer

The CloudApplicationContextInitializer will do two things:
- active the "cloud" profile
- add a PropertySource featuring Cloud Foundry specific properties

Properties provided by the PropertySource are automatically available via
Spring's property placeholder.  These two features make configuring Spring
applications to use Cloud Foundry services even easier.

This class implements Ordered with a default value of 0.  Other
ApplicationContextInitializer's can define a higher order to ensure this
classes properties are defined first.

Note: Spring 3.1 (or later) is required

Change-Id: Id0db74fc79f2b3804d2b27a199368bf85896140c

More advanced property support.

Introducing CloudEnvironment#getCloudProperties() which provides cloud specific
properties about the environment, application and bound services.

General properties take the form:
cloud.application.name = helloworld
cloud.provider.url = cloudfoundry.com

Service specific properties are also exposed for each bound service:
cloud.services.customerDb.type = mysql-5.1
cloud.services.customerDb.plan = free
cloud.services.customerDb.connection.hostname = ...
cloud.services.customerDb.connection.port = ...
etc...

If a there is only a single service of a given type, that service is aliased to
the service type.  For example, if there is only a single MySQL service bound
to the application, the service properties will also be exposed under the
'mysql' key:
cloud.services.mysql.type = mysql-5.1
cloud.services.mysql.plan = free
cloud.services.mysql.connection.hostname = ...
cloud.services.mysql.connection.port = ...
etc...

Introducing CloudEnvironment#isCloudFoundry() helper which returns true if
running within a Cloud Foundry environment.

Introducing cloud:properties which exposes the output of
CloudEnvironment#getCloudProperties as a bean.

Deprecating <cloud:service-properties /> in favor of <cloud:properties />

Change-Id: I16f9235baff471a0cde7f61b1ab78a62cd431733

Add a validation query for MySQL connection pools, testing on borrow.

For Java applications, MySQL connections in the DBCP pool currently timeout
after (approximately 8) hours of inactivity.  The first request that needs a
live connection will fail.  In order to ensure that all connections dispensed
by the pool are valid, we are adding a validation query that is tested before
the connection is retrieved from the pool.

The validation query was obtained from the MySQL reference manual:
http://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/5.1/en/connector-j-usagenotes-j2ee.html
"/* ping */ SELECT 1"

Testing on borrow will add slight overhead for requests needing a database
connection as the validation query needs to execute before the connection is
returned by the pool.  testOnBorrow is the best option provided by DBCP.

Over time, we should evaluate alternative connection pools.  For example: the
Tomcat connection pool introduced alongside Tomcat 7 (also compatible with
Tomcat 6) offers higher concurrency within the pool, and has more/better
options for validating connections.

Topic: merge
